questions.question: Which organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are called the powerhouse of the cell because they carry out aerobic respiration and generate ATP (energy currency) needed for various cellular activities. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: Who discovered the cell?
questions.explanation: Robert Hooke discovered the cell in 1665 by observing thin slices of cork under a simple magnifying device. He saw honeycomb-like compartments which he called 'cells'. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: Which of the following cell organelles is absent in animal cells?
questions.explanation: Cell wall is present in plant cells but absent in animal cells. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose outside the plasma membrane, which provides structural support. Animal cells have only the plasma membrane. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: The nucleus of a prokaryotic cell is called:
questions.explanation: Prokaryotic cells lack a well-defined nucleus. Their nuclear material (DNA) is not enclosed by a nuclear membrane and lies in a region called the nucleoid. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: Which organelle is known as the 'suicide bags' of the cell?
questions.explanation: Lysosomes are called suicide bags because they contain powerful digestive enzymes. When a cell gets damaged or old, lysosomes burst and the enzymes digest the entire cell. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: If the plasma membrane of a cell is placed in a hypotonic solution, what will happen?
options: The cell will shrink due to exosmosis
The cell will lose all its organelles
There will be no change in the cell
The cell will swell up due to endosmosis
questions.explanation: In a hypotonic solution (lower solute concentration outside), water moves into the cell by endosmosis (osmosis inward), causing the cell to swell. This is because water moves from a region of higher water concentration (outside) to lower water concentration (inside the cell). NCERT Class 9 Chapter 5.

questions.question: Which type of tissue is responsible for the growth of plants?
questions.explanation: Meristematic tissue is responsible for the growth of plants. These tissues have cells that divide actively and are found at the growing tips of roots and shoots (apical meristem). NCERT Class 9 Chapter 6.

questions.question: Which type of connective tissue connects muscles to bones?
questions.explanation: Tendons connect muscles to bones. They are strong, fibrous connective tissues with great strength but limited flexibility. Ligaments, on the other hand, connect bones to bones. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 6.

questions.question: The tissue that transports water in plants is:
questions.explanation: Xylem is the vascular tissue responsible for transporting water and dissolved minerals from the roots to all parts of the plant. Phloem transports food materials (sucrose) from leaves to other parts. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 6.

questions.question: Voluntary muscles are also known as:
questions.explanation: Striated (skeletal) muscles are voluntary muscles because they work under our conscious control. They are attached to bones and help in body movements. They have alternating light and dark bands (striations) under a microscope. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 6.

questions.question: The tissue that provides flexibility to plant parts like leaf stalks is:
questions.explanation: Collenchyma provides flexibility to plant parts such as leaf stalks (petioles). It has cells with irregularly thickened corners that allow bending without breaking. This is why leaves can bend in the wind without snapping. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 6.

questions.question: Who proposed the Five Kingdom classification of living organisms?
questions.explanation: R.H. Whittaker proposed the Five Kingdom classification in 1969. The five kingdoms are Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. This classification is based on cell structure, mode and source of nutrition, and body organization. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which kingdom includes organisms that are prokaryotic?
questions.explanation: Kingdom Monera includes all prokaryotic organisms (organisms without a well-defined nucleus). This includes bacteria and blue-green algae (cyanobacteria). All other kingdoms have eukaryotic organisms. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 7.

questions.question: The binomial nomenclature system was introduced by:
questions.explanation: Carolus Linnaeus introduced the binomial nomenclature system, where every organism is given a two-part scientific name — the first part is the genus name and the second part is the species name. For example, Homo sapiens for humans. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Mushrooms belong to which kingdom?
questions.explanation: Mushrooms belong to Kingdom Fungi. Fungi are heterotrophic eukaryotic organisms that have a cell wall made of chitin. They are saprophytic (feed on dead organic matter) or parasitic. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which group of plants produces seeds but not fruits?
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms produce seeds that are not enclosed in fruits (naked seeds). The word 'gymnosperm' means 'naked seed'. Examples include pine, deodar, and cycas. Angiosperms, on the other hand, have seeds enclosed within fruits. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which of the following is a viral disease?
questions.explanation: Influenza (common cold) is caused by a virus (rhinovirus). Typhoid and tuberculosis are bacterial diseases, and malaria is caused by a protozoan (Plasmodium). NCERT Class 9 Chapter 13.

questions.question: Malaria is caused by which type of organism?
questions.explanation: Malaria is caused by the protozoan Plasmodium, which is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 13.

questions.question: Which of the following is a means of preventing infectious diseases?
questions.explanation: Vaccination is a key method of preventing infectious diseases. Vaccines introduce weakened or killed pathogens into the body, which stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies and develop immunity against that disease. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 13.

questions.question: Antibiotics work against which type of disease-causing organisms?
questions.explanation: Antibiotics (like penicillin) are effective against bacteria. They block the biochemical pathways important for bacteria. Antibiotics do not work against viral infections because viruses use the host cell's machinery and do not have their own biochemical pathways. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 13.

questions.question: Which gas is fixed by Rhizobium bacteria in the nitrogen cycle?
questions.explanation: Rhizobium bacteria fix atmospheric nitrogen (N2) into usable forms like nitrates and nitrites. These bacteria live in the root nodules of leguminous plants (like peas, beans) and have a symbiotic relationship with the plant. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 14.

questions.question: Which process returns carbon dioxide to the atmosphere in the carbon cycle?
questions.explanation: Respiration (by organisms) and combustion (burning of fossil fuels) return CO2 to the atmosphere. Photosynthesis, on the other hand, removes CO2 from the atmosphere and converts it to glucose. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 14.

questions.question: The water cycle is driven primarily by:
questions.explanation: The water cycle is primarily driven by solar energy. The sun heats water bodies causing evaporation, which forms clouds. These clouds then bring rain, completing the cycle. NCERT Class 9 Chapter 14.

questions.question: Hybridisation refers to crossing between:
options: Genetically dissimilar plants to obtain desired traits
questions.explanation: Hybridisation is the process of crossing between genetically dissimilar plants to combine desirable characters from both parents. This can be intervarietal (between different varieties), interspecific (between species of the same genus), or intergeneric (between different genera). NCERT Class 9 Chapter 15.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Kharif crop?
questions.explanation: Paddy (rice) is a Kharif crop grown during the rainy season (June to October). Wheat, mustard, and gram are Rabi crops grown during the winter season (October to March). NCERT Class 9 Chapter 15.

questions.question: Which is the correct sequence of passage of air during inhalation?
options: Nostrils → Trachea → Pharynx → Larynx → Bronchi → Alveoli
Nostrils → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Alveoli
Nostrils → Pharynx → Trachea → Larynx → Bronchi → Alveoli
Nostrils → Larynx → Pharynx → Trachea → Alveoli → Bronchi
questions.explanation: During inhalation, air passes through: Nostrils → Pharynx (throat) → Larynx (voice box) → Trachea (windpipe) → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli, where gas exchange occurs. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: The main organ of excretion in humans is the:
questions.explanation: The kidneys are the main excretory organs in humans. They filter blood to remove waste products like urea and excess water, forming urine. Each kidney contains about a million filtering units called nephrons. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: In which part of the digestive system is the food finally absorbed into the blood?
questions.explanation: The small intestine is the main site of absorption of digested food into the blood. Its inner lining has millions of tiny finger-like projections called villi, which increase the surface area for efficient absorption of nutrients. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: Which blood vessel carries blood from the heart to the lungs?
questions.explanation: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle of the heart to the lungs for oxygenation. It is the only artery that carries deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the left atrium. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: Autotrophic nutrition involves:
options: Depending on a host organism for food
Making food from simple inorganic substances using light energy
questions.explanation: Autotrophic nutrition is the process where organisms make their own food from simple inorganic substances like CO2 and water using light energy (photosynthesis). Green plants are the most common examples of autotrophs. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: The functional unit of the kidney is the:
questions.explanation: The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney. Each kidney contains approximately one million nephrons. A nephron consists of a Bowman's capsule (containing the glomerulus), proximal tubule, loop of Henle, distal tubule, and collecting duct. It filters blood and forms urine. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 6.

questions.question: The functional unit of the nervous system is the:
questions.explanation: The neuron (nerve cell) is the functional unit of the nervous system. It carries messages in the form of electrical impulses (nerve impulses) from one part of the body to another. A neuron has three parts: cell body, dendrite, and axon. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 7.

questions.question: A reflex arc consists of the following pathway:
options: Effector → Sensory nerve → Spinal cord → Motor nerve → Receptor
Receptor → Sensory nerve → Spinal cord → Motor nerve → Effector
Receptor → Motor nerve → Brain → Sensory nerve → Effector
questions.explanation: A reflex arc is the pathway of a reflex action: Receptor (sense organ) → Sensory (afferent) nerve → Spinal cord (processing center) → Motor (efferent) nerve → Effector (muscle or gland). Reflex actions are quick, automatic, involuntary responses that do not involve the brain. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which hormone is secreted by the pancreas to lower blood sugar levels?
questions.explanation: Insulin is secreted by the beta cells of the Islets of Langerhans in the pancreas. It lowers blood sugar levels by promoting the uptake of glucose by body cells and its conversion to glycogen for storage. Deficiency of insulin causes diabetes mellitus. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 7.

questions.question: The movement of a plant part in response to light is called:
questions.explanation: Phototropism is the growth movement of a plant part towards or away from light. Shoots show positive phototropism (grow towards light) while roots show negative phototropism (grow away from light). This is regulated by the plant hormone auxin. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which part of the brain controls involuntary actions such as blood pressure, salivation, and vomiting?
questions.explanation: The medulla oblongata (part of the hindbrain) controls involuntary actions like blood pressure, heart rate, salivation, vomiting, and breathing. The cerebrum handles thinking and voluntary actions, while the cerebellum maintains balance and posture. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 7.

questions.question: Binary fission is observed in:
questions.explanation: Binary fission is observed in Amoeba. In this process, the parent organism splits into two equal halves, each forming a new individual. The nucleus divides first, followed by the cytoplasm. It is a type of asexual reproduction. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 8.

questions.question: Budding is a mode of reproduction commonly seen in:
questions.explanation: Budding is commonly seen in Hydra. A small outgrowth (bud) develops on the body of the parent organism, grows, and eventually detaches to form a new independent organism. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 8.

questions.question: What is the role of the placenta in human reproduction?
options: It provides nourishment and oxygen to the developing embryo
It protects the embryo from infections only
questions.explanation: The placenta is a special tissue connection between the embryo and the uterine wall. It provides nourishment (glucose, oxygen) from the mother's blood to the developing embryo and removes waste products from the embryo's blood. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 8.

questions.question: The male reproductive cells in flowering plants are produced in the:
questions.explanation: The anther produces pollen grains, which contain the male reproductive cells (male gametes). The anther is the top part of the stamen (the male reproductive organ of a flower). During pollination, pollen grains are transferred from the anther to the stigma. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 8.

questions.question: Vegetative propagation is a type of:
questions.explanation: Vegetative propagation is a type of asexual reproduction in which new plants grow from parts of the parent plant (such as roots, stems, or leaves) without the involvement of seeds. Examples include potato (tuber), rose (stem cutting), and Bryophyllum (leaf buds). NCERT Class 10 Chapter 8.

questions.question: Gregor Mendel conducted his experiments on:
questions.explanation: Gregor Mendel, the father of genetics, conducted his famous experiments on pea plants (Pisum sativum). He chose pea plants because they had many contrasting characters, short generation time, and could be easily cross-pollinated. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 9.

questions.question: If both parents are heterozygous for a trait (Tt x Tt), what ratio of phenotypes is expected in the offspring?
questions.explanation: When both parents are heterozygous (Tt x Tt), the offspring will have a phenotypic ratio of 3:1 (3 dominant : 1 recessive). The genotypic ratio will be 1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt. This is Mendel's Law of Segregation in action. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 9.

questions.question: The sex of a child in humans is determined by:
questions.explanation: In humans, the sex of the child is determined by the father's chromosomes. Males have XY sex chromosomes and produce two types of sperm (X and Y). Females have XX chromosomes and produce only X-type eggs. If an X-bearing sperm fertilises the egg, the child is female (XX). If a Y-bearing sperm fertilises the egg, the child is male (XY). NCERT Class 10 Chapter 9.

questions.question: Analogous organs provide evidence for:
questions.explanation: Analogous organs (organs with different internal structures but similar functions) provide evidence for convergent evolution. For example, wings of birds and wings of insects look similar and serve the same function (flight) but have different origins. This shows organisms evolved similar solutions to similar environments independently. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 9.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of homologous organs?
options: Wings of a bird and wings of an insect
Wings of a bird and wings of a bat
Eyes of an octopus and eyes of a human
Fins of a fish and flippers of a whale only
questions.explanation: Wings of a bird and wings (forelimbs) of a bat are homologous organs — they have the same basic structural plan and origin (forelimb bones) but perform different functions in some cases. Homologous organs provide evidence for divergent evolution from a common ancestor. Wings of a bird and wings of an insect are analogous organs (similar function, different origin). NCERT Class 10 Chapter 9.

questions.question: In a food chain, the organisms that make their own food are called:
questions.explanation: Producers are organisms (mainly green plants) that make their own food through photosynthesis. They form the first trophic level in any food chain. All other organisms directly or indirectly depend on producers for their food. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to the 10% law of energy transfer, if the producers in an ecosystem have 10,000 J of energy, how much energy will be available to the second-level consumers?
questions.explanation: According to the 10% law (proposed by Lindeman), only 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next. Producers: 10,000 J → Primary consumers: 1,000 J → Secondary (second-level) consumers: 100 J. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 15.

questions.question: The 'three Rs' to save the environment are:
questions.explanation: The three Rs to save the environment are Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again without processing), and Recycle (collect and process waste materials to make new products). These strategies help conserve natural resources and reduce pollution. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 16.

questions.question: The Chipko Movement was associated with the conservation of:
questions.explanation: The Chipko Movement (meaning 'to hug') was a forest conservation movement started in the Garhwal Himalayas in the 1970s. Local villagers, especially women, hugged trees to prevent them from being cut down by contractors. It became a symbol of community-based environmental activism. NCERT Class 10 Chapter 16.
